results.title: Navajo children
results.creator_credit: Classroom Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Set in Arizona and New Mexico, this is a charming film showing the home life of a family of Navajo Indians, and includes a record of their annual trek from winter to summer pasturelands for their herds of sheep, goats and horses.
results.description: Set in Arizona and New Mexico, this is a charming film showing the home life of a family of Navajo Indians, and includes a record of their annual trek from winter to summer pasturelands for their herds of sheep, goats and horses.

results.title: Naughty nostalgia. - Volume 1 (E)
results.brief_description: This video contains three of the earliest known pornographic films of the 1920s era. Each is shown complete with the original title cards, honky tonk music track, vintage automobiles and black stockings and hats of the day.

results.title: Naughty cartoons (E)
results.brief_description: A patchy collection of cult, unusual and obscure ‘erotic’ based animation. As a whole overtly designed to titillate on the most obvious level (these animations being the least affective), with only a few having any merit. Generally an over-use of ‘visual friction’ throughout. Some of the better ones: Karl Krogsta’s clay animation Jack in the Fox, Susan Pittkraning’s drawing based Crocus, Lapoujade’s L’ombre De La Pomme (with jazz soundtrack). The fifteen plus cartoons represent pornographic animation from the early 1900’s to contemporary times.

results.title: Nature walkabout
results.creator_credit: Vincent Serventy, William Copland and Cardin Film Service
results.brief_description: Wildlife in and around the city of Perth and the southern areas and coastlines of West Australia. Shows a variety of animals going about their daily experiences with a main focus on birdlife. Written and photographed by Vincent and Carol Serventy. Narrated by Kevin Golsby.

results.title: Nature of colour
results.brief_description: Colour is explained as mental reactions to varying wave lengths of visible light, and the application of scientific colour principles in the arts, colour printing, and photography, is studied. (Optimum projection conditions are necessary if this film is to be a really useful teaching aid, as it relies very largely on the fact that it is a colour film to make its thesis clear.)

results.title: Nature of Australia: a portrait of the Island Continent
results.creator_credit: David Parer, Dione Gilmour, ABC-TV (Australia) and ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit
results.brief_description: A visually stunning television series that shows the formation of Australia as an Island Continent and the evolution of our exotic flora and fauna. “A Separate Creation” looks at the development of Australian marsupials, in particular kangaroos. “Seas Under Capricorn” shows the extremes of marine environments that surround Australia - from the warmth of the Barrier Reef to the cold of the Antarctic. “The Making of the Bush” shows the development of forest and the wildlife it sustains. “The Sunburnt Country” deals with the large interior of Australia that is predominately desert. “Land of Flood and Fire” shows the extremes in weather the continent is subjected to and how fire forms a part of managing the land. All five programs that make up the series run for approximately 50 minutes each. Written by John Vandenbeld and Narrated by Robyn Williams.

All five programs that make up the series run for approximately 50 minutes each. Written by John Vandenbeld and Narrated by Robyn Williams.

results.title: Nature of Australia. Parts 4-6 (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: David Parer, Dione Gilmour and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: The Sunburnt country tells the story of Australia’s arid interior, formed when climatic change overtook and dried out Central Australia. “Land of flood and fire” portrays a year in the life of the spectacular far north coast of Australia, where the first Aboriginal people arrived and settled. The region swings savagely between the floods of the annual wet and the parched heat of the dry season. “The End of isolation” examines the impact of the European invasion which sent change sweeping across the continent with unprecedented speed.
